Hellscape Chatterbane Shortsword (Very R.name: Hellscape Chatterbane Shortsword (Very Rare)
Hellscape Chatterbane Shortsword (Very R.description:
Weapon, very rare
Martial weapon, melee weapon 2 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] piercing - finesse, light

When metal is in short supply, devils and demons alike turn to more plentiful resources of the Lower Planes: teeth, bones, and molten rock. The skull of a hellscape chatterbane is often the focus of the magical enchantments weaved into it, producing flame from its eye sockets and laughter from its mouth.

While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.eCPQuQkIabFKTl9u]{Produce Flame} cantrip as an 11th-level caster (+8 to hit).

Posthumous Mirth. As an action, you can shake the weapon to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.BQk5Row4NymMnUQl]{Hideous Laughter} spell (save DC 16), causing the skull's jaw to rattle up and down, and a malevolent cackling sound to fill the air. Once this property of the weapon has been used seven times, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Hellscape Chatterbane Trident (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, melee weapon 4 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] piercing - thrown (20/60 ft.), versatile ([[/r 1d8]])

When metal is in short supply, devils and demons alike turn to more plentiful resources of the Lower Planes: teeth, bones, and molten rock. The skull of a hellscape chatterbane is often the focus of the magical enchantments weaved into it, producing flame from its eye sockets and laughter from its mouth.

While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.eCPQuQkIabFKTl9u]{Produce Flame} cantrip (+5 to hit).

Posthumous Mirth. As an action, you can shake the weapon to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.BQk5Row4NymMnUQl]{Hideous Laughter} spell (save DC 13), causing the skull's jaw to rattle up and down, and a malevolent cackling sound to fill the air. Once this property of the weapon has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Thrown. If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Abyssal Bane Halberd (Uncommon).name: Abyssal Bane Halberd (Uncommon)
Abyssal Bane Halberd (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, melee weapon 6 lb.
[[/r 1d10]] slashing - heavy, reach, two-handed

Fashioned of bone, stone, and demon eyes, abyssal weapons are gestated by unholy bonesmiths within the infernal depths of the Hells. Fortified by magic to prevent the brittle materials from shattering, such weapons are carved with the true name of the demon whose eyes were 'donated' to its conception.

The power of such a weapon is linked to the number of eyes used to craft it, with each open eye representing one unexpended charge. This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

Bonerip. As a bonus action when you hit a target with this weapon, you can call the name of the demon to whom the eyes belonged and expend 1 charge. The weapon mobilises, boney teeth and necrotic energy ripping through the target's defences. The target gains a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to its AC. Its AC can't be reduced to less than 10 + its Dexterity modifier. The target can repair its armour with enough rest (for natural armour) or at an appropriate armoursmith's (for worn armour) at the GM's discretion.

Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Reach. This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it. This property also determines your reach for opportunity attacks with a reach weapon.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Wings of the Hellspawn (Uncommon).name: Wings of the Hellspawn (Uncommon)
Wings of the Hellspawn (Uncommon).description:
Wondrous item, uncommon (requires attunement)

The membranes of these wings are almost transparent in bright daylight, the bones appearing like fleshless claws. Come night or thick shadow, the membranes coalesce into blood-red curtains of opaque, ragged flesh. As you attune to this item, bands of sinew wrap around your form, binding you to these grotesque bone-and-membrane wings.

Until your attunement to the wings ends, you can't be parted from them, willingly or otherwise.

Fiendish Flight. When you fall and aren't incapacitated, you can subtract up to 100 feet from the fall when calculating falling damage, and you can move up to 2 feet horizontally for every 1 foot you descend.

Devil's Cocoon. As an action, you can cause these wings to wrap around you, forming a fleshy carapace. You gain [[/r 1d4 + 4]] temporary hit points that last for 1 hour. If you use the Fiendish Flight property, you lose any temporary hit points you have from this property. Once this property of the wings has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Enrage.name: Enrage
Enrage.description:
You attempt to create violent emotions in a group of people. Each humanoid in a 20-foot-radius sphere centred on a point you choose within range must make a Charisma saving throw; a creature can choose to fail this saving throw if it wishes. A creature that fails this saving throw becomes enraged for the duration.

While enraged, a target becomes hostile towards all creatures. An enraged creature that is concentrating on a spell must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw at the start of each of its turns or lose concentration on the spell.

As an action, you can force an enraged creature to use its reaction to make one melee weapon attack against one randomly determined creature within the enraged creature's reach. If the enraged creature was friendly towards the target of its attack before this spell was cast, the enraged creature can repeat the saving throw immediately after making the attack, ending the effect on itself on a success.

An enraged creature can repeat the saving throw whenever it takes damage, ending the effect on itself on a success. When the spell ends, the creature reverts to its previous disposition again, unless the GM rules otherwise.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher and use an action to force an enraged creature to make a melee weapon attack, you can force one additional enraged creature to make a melee weapon attack for each slot level above 3rd.

Heart of Stone (Rare).name: Heart of Stone (Rare)
Heart of Stone (Rare).description:
Wondrous item, rare (requires attunement)

When a fiend dies near this fist-sized lump of obsidian, its soul is incarcerated within its inky confines. A creature that attunes to this petrified devil's heart learns the name of any soul imprisoned within it and can drain the soul's lifeforce to create powerful magic. However, with each interaction, there is always a chance that the fiend can break free of this stony jail.

The heart can be used as a spellcasting focus for your spells.

Soultrap. When a fiend of CR 12 or lower dies within 10 feet of the heart and the heart doesn't already have a soul trapped within it, the fiend's soul becomes trapped within the heart. The heart gains a number of charges equal to the maximum number of Hit Dice the fiend possessed. If all these charges are expended, the soul is shredded and destroyed. While you hold the stone, you can communicate telepathically with the imprisoned soul, if it is willing. You can release an imprisoned soul back to the Lower Planes as an action.

Soulshred. While you hold the heart, you can expend charges from it to cast the following spells (save DC 15): @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.95K2aUhAGV9qXjnf]{Bane} (1 charge), @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.pO4zGe5LmFIYqJiL]{Bestow Curse} (3 charges), @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.3MYDjS6k9IYL0aTj]{Calm Emotions} (2 charges), @Compendium[larsene-ledger-treasures-and-trinkets.loot-tavern-16-nine-hells-item.2e7hAnaDyrscVj59]{Enrage} (2 charges), @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.XZhdgVK3cLoxNCQl]{Remove Curse} (3 charges). After you cast a spell in this way, you must make a Charisma check contested by the imprisoned fiend's. On a failure, the fiend's soul escapes and is released back to the Lower Planes, and the heart loses all its remaining charges. If a soul escapes or is released while you're on one of the Lower Planes, the fiend can immediately materialise with all of its hit points in an unoccupied space within 10 feet of the heart.

Pitbone Arrow (Very Rare).description:
Ammunition, very rare

These crude arrows thrum with energy, ready to shatter upon impact. The flights—pitcrow feathers—are enchanted to flare when a target is missed, turning the arrow to the ground where it erupts in a cloud of bone fragments. Hit or miss, these single-use arrows are a nuisance on the battlefield.

Hit. When you hit with this arrow, the target must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or have shattered bone fragments lodged in obtrusive places within its body. While a creature has these fragments in it, it takes 4 piercing damage when it moves for the first time on a turn and whenever it takes the Attack action. As an action, an affected creature can make a DC 16 Wisdom (Medicine) check, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Miss. When you miss with this arrow, the arrow changes direction to hit the nearest surface to the target, where it explodes into sharp fragments. Each creature within 5 feet of the arrow must succeed on a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw or take [[/r 1d12]] piercing damage.

Nothing so delicate as glass or so pure as silver survives long on the Lower Planes. That in itself makes this magic item a rarity. Held by a handle of claw-like fingers, this magic mirror grants its user the ability to see who is truly the fairest of them all.

Real Reflections. As an action while holding the mirror, you can speak its command word to cause its reflective surface to disappear for 1 minute. During that time, a creature that looks through the mirror while holding it has truesight out to 60 feet. Once this property of the mirror has been used twice, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Hellscape Chatterbane War Crescent (Rare.name: Hellscape Chatterbane War Crescent (Rare)
Hellscape Chatterbane War Crescent (Rare.description:
Weapon, rare
Simple weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d6]] slashing - versatile ([[/r 1d8]])

When metal is in short supply, devils and demons alike turn to more plentiful resources of the Lower Planes: teeth, bones, and molten rock. The skull of a hellscape chatterbane is often the focus of the magical enchantments weaved into it, producing flame from its eye sockets and laughter from its mouth.

While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.eCPQuQkIabFKTl9u]{Produce Flame} cantrip as a 5th-level caster (+7 to hit).

Posthumous Mirth. As an action, you can shake the weapon to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.BQk5Row4NymMnUQl]{Hideous Laughter} spell (save DC 15), causing the skull's jaw to rattle up and down, and a malevolent cackling sound to fill the air. Once this property of the weapon has been used four times, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

War crescents are simple melee weapons consisting of large, convex curved blades, meant to be wielded with one or two hands. They deal [[/r 1d6]] slashing damage on a hit, and have the Versatile ([[/r 1d8]]) property.

Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Abyssal Bane Spiked Cestus (Very Rare).description:
Weapon, very rare
Simple weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d6]] bludgeoning - alt. [[/r 1d6]], Adaptable (P), attached, pugilist

Fashioned of bone, stone, and demon eyes, abyssal weapons are gestated by unholy bonesmiths within the infernal depths of the Hells. Fortified by magic to prevent the brittle materials from shattering, such weapons are carved with the true name of the demon whose eyes were 'donated' to its conception.

The power of such a weapon is linked to the number of eyes used to craft it, with each open eye representing one unexpended charge. This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Bonerip. As a bonus action when you hit a target with this weapon, you can call the name of the demon to whom the eyes belonged and expend 1 charge. The weapon mobilises, boney teeth and necrotic energy ripping through the target's defences. The target gains a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to its AC. Its AC can't be reduced to less than 10 + its Dexterity modifier. The target can repair its armour with enough rest (for natural armour) or at an appropriate armoursmith's (for worn armour) at the GM's discretion.

A spiked cestus is a simple melee weapon worn around the knuckles of one hand that deals [[/r 1d6]] bludgeoning damage on a hit and has the Adaptable (piercing), Attached, and Pugilist properties.

Attached. You can't be disarmed of this weapon, but donning or doffing the weapon takes an action. You can use a hand equipped with this weapon to hold items, but can't attack with the weapon while doing so. Additionally, you have disadvantage on attack rolls using other weapons held in a hand equipped with this weapon and on Sleight of Hand checks using the hand that is equipped with this weapon.

Pugilist. For creatures that roll a die when they make unarmed strikes (such as the monk or tavern brawler fighter), the size of their damage die is increased by one (maximum 1d12) when they make unarmed strikes with a hand equipped with a weapon that has this property.

Adaptable. This weapon can be used with differing techniques, allowing it to deal different types of damage. A damage type in parentheses appears with the property—when a creature makes a weapon attack with this weapon, it can choose either the weapon's normal damage type or this damage type.

Heart of Stone (Very Rare).name: Heart of Stone (Very Rare)
Heart of Stone (Very Rare).description:
Wondrous item, very rare (requires attunement)

When a fiend dies near this fist-sized lump of obsidian, its soul is incarcerated within its inky confines. A creature that attunes to this petrified devil's heart learns the name of any soul imprisoned within it and can drain the soul's lifeforce to create powerful magic. However, with each interaction, there is always a chance that the fiend can break free of this stony jail.

The heart can be used as a spellcasting focus for your spells.

Soultrap. When a fiend of CR 18 or lower dies within 10 feet of the heart and the heart doesn't already have a soul trapped within it, the fiend's soul becomes trapped within the heart. The heart gains a number of charges equal to the maximum number of Hit Dice the fiend possessed. If all these charges are expended, the soul is shredded and destroyed. While you hold the stone, you can communicate telepathically with the imprisoned soul, if it is willing. You can release an imprisoned soul back to the Lower Planes as an action.

Soulshred. While you hold the heart, you can expend charges from it to cast the following spells (save DC 16): @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.95K2aUhAGV9qXjnf]{Bane} (1 charge), @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.pO4zGe5LmFIYqJiL]{Bestow Curse} (3 charges), @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.3MYDjS6k9IYL0aTj]{Calm Emotions} (2 charges), @Compendium[larsene-ledger-treasures-and-trinkets.loot-tavern-16-nine-hells-item.2e7hAnaDyrscVj59]{Enrage} (2 charges), @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.XZhdgVK3cLoxNCQl]{Remove Curse} (3 charges), @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.ReMbjfeOKoSj3O79]{Stoneskin} (4 charges, when cast this way, the target's skin resembles the obsidian of the heart). After you cast a spell in this way, you must make a Charisma check contested by the imprisoned fiend's. On a failure, the fiend's soul escapes and is released back to the Lower Planes, and the heart loses all its remaining charges. If a soul escapes or is released while you're on one of the Lower Planes, the fiend can immediately materialise with all of its hit points in an unoccupied space within 10 feet of the heart.

Hewn from a deformed demon's skull, this armour allows its bearer to rival the resistances of fiends. Energy is drawn in through its mouth and channelled to the eyes, where it is stored until unleashed in an elemental rebuke.

This armour has 4 charges and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

Consume Energy. When you take cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage, you can use your reaction to speak the armour's first command word and expend 1 charge. The mouth opens, consuming some of the incoming energy. You gain resistance to the triggering damage and one of the armour's eyes lights up with the stored energy. The armour has two eyes, and an eye can't store more energy if it already is storing some.

Unleash Energy. When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can utter the armour's second command word, unleashing the energy stored in all of the armour's eyes. For each eye that was storing energy, the creature takes [[/r 1d8]] damage of the stored type, after which the stored energy disappears.

Emberink Stationery (Very Rare).name: Emberink Stationery (Very Rare)
Emberink Stationery (Very Rare).description:
Wondrous item, very rare (requires attunement)

Filtered from fiendish blood, this pot of fiery orange ink melts most mundane quills that dare to dip into its contents. Only its compatriot, the enchanted pitbat quill which forms part of the stationery, can contain the lava-like liquid. An emberink stationery is often used as a training tool for new devils, promoting teamwork and the virtues of adhering to a contract.

Charges & Charging. An emberink stationery can hold a maximum of 4 charges, contains [[/r 1d4]] charges when found, and regains charges when the ink pot is used to capture a fiend's blood. As fiends' bodies disappear from the Material Plane on death, fiendish blood must be extracted while the fiend is still alive. You can use an action to extract blood from a living fiend within your reach. If the fiend is unwilling, the fiend must be restrained or incapacitated and be below half of its maximum hit points. When blood is extracted in this way, the stationery regains a number of charges equal to a roll of one of the fiend's Hit Dice, and once it regains charges, it can't do so again until the next dawn.

Contractual Obligation. As an action, you can use the stationery to write on the skin of a willing humanoid. The ink burns into the flesh of your target, raking a cauterised scar, while an identical burn appears in a similar place on your own body. Both you and the creature take 1 fire damage. Choose one of the following glyphs and expend the appropriate number of charges; for 1 hour, you are both subjected to the associated magical effects.

  • Ward (1 charge). While you and the creature are within 30 feet of one another, you both have a +1 bonus to AC. While you are more than 30 feet apart, you both suffer a -1 penalty to AC.

  • Warp (2 charges). While you and the creature are within 30 feet of one another, each affected creature can choose whether it is enlarged or reduced, as per the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.WahI41a3goVUg0x1]{Enlarge/Reduce} spell. An affected creature can use its action to return to normal size, or to enlarge or reduce itself if it's already normal size. While you are more than 30 feet apart, both creatures return to their normal size.

  • Wrath (1 charge). While you and the creature are within 30 feet of one another, you both gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls. While you are more than 30 feet apart, you both suffer a -1 penalty to attack and damage rolls.

Once the stationery has been used to sign a glyph, the ink turns dark and it can't be used again until the current contract is complete (i.e., the hour has elapsed).

Bloodshot Musket (Very Rare).name: Bloodshot Musket (Very Rare)
Bloodshot Musket (Very Rare).description:
Weapon, very rare
Firearm, martial weapon, ranged weapon [[/r 1d10]] piercing - ammunition (80/240 ft.), Loud (1000), Reload (1), two-handed

Ever parched, this sinister firearm greedily drinks any lifeblood it's offered, and an otherworldly mechanism inside it converts it into deadly shards, which it fires instead of bullets. The slightest trickle of crimson is enough for the pupils on this hellish weapon to dilate and for its eyes to appear wild and bloodshot.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Feed the Beast. This weapon has 10 charges. Over the course of a short or long rest, any creature can cause bloodshot to regain expended charges by dripping their own blood down its barrel and spending Hit Dice. Roll each Hit Die spent in this way, and the weapon regains a number of charges equal to the total. After absorbing 3 Hit Dice worth of blood, the weapon can't absorb more blood in this way until the next dawn.

Alternatively, over the course of a minute, you can extract blood from the corpse of a creature that has been dead for no longer than 10 minutes. When you do so, the weapon gains a number of charges equal to the roll of one of the dead creature's Hit Dice. After absorbing the blood from a corpse in this way, the weapon can't do so again until 1 hour has passed.

Shot Selection. This weapon doesn't have the reload or ammunition properties. Instead, in order to make a ranged weapon attack with it, you must spend charges in one of the following ways:

  • Bloodshard (1 charge). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage.

  • Septic Shock (3 charges). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage and the target must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the end of its next turn as its blood becomes corrupted. A creature immune to disease automatically succeeds on this saving throw.

An inaccurate rifle that deals [[/r 1d10]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 80/240), Loud (1000), Reload (1), and Two-handed properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Loud (X). The sound of the weapon discharging alerts all hearing creatures within a number of feet as specified by the number in parentheses after the loud property. This range is doubled in echoey locations, such as cave systems, and where sound travels faster, such as underwater.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Heart of Stone (Uncommon).name: Heart of Stone (Uncommon)
Heart of Stone (Uncommon).description:
Wondrous item, uncommon (requires attunement)

When a fiend dies near this fist-sized lump of obsidian, its soul is incarcerated within its inky confines. A creature that attunes to this petrified devil's heart learns the name of any soul imprisoned within it and can drain the soul's lifeforce to create powerful magic. However, with each interaction, there is always a chance that the fiend can break free of this stony jail.

The heart can be used as a spellcasting focus for your spells.

Soultrap. When a fiend of CR 6 or lower dies within 10 feet of the heart and the heart doesn't already have a soul trapped within it, the fiend's soul becomes trapped within the heart. The heart gains a number of charges equal to the maximum number of Hit Dice the fiend possessed. If all these charges are expended, the soul is shredded and destroyed. While you hold the stone, you can communicate telepathically with the imprisoned soul, if it is willing. You can release an imprisoned soul back to the Lower Planes as an action.

Soulshred. While you hold the heart, you can expend charges from it to cast the following spells (save DC 13): @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.95K2aUhAGV9qXjnf]{Bane} (1 charge), @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.3MYDjS6k9IYL0aTj]{Calm Emotions} (2 charges), @Compendium[larsene-ledger-treasures-and-trinkets.loot-tavern-16-nine-hells-item.2e7hAnaDyrscVj59]{Enrage} (2 charges). After you cast a spell in this way, you must make a Charisma check contested by the imprisoned fiend's. On a failure, the fiend's soul escapes and is released back to the Lower Planes, and the heart loses all its remaining charges. If a soul escapes or is released while you're on one of the Lower Planes, the fiend can immediately materialise with all of its hit points in an unoccupied space within 10 feet of the heart.

Abyssal Bane Knuckle Duster (Uncommon).name: Abyssal Bane Knuckle Duster (Uncommon)
Abyssal Bane Knuckle Duster (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Simple weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d4]] bludgeoning - attached, light, pugilist

Fashioned of bone, stone, and demon eyes, abyssal weapons are gestated by unholy bonesmiths within the infernal depths of the Hells. Fortified by magic to prevent the brittle materials from shattering, such weapons are carved with the true name of the demon whose eyes were 'donated' to its conception.

The power of such a weapon is linked to the number of eyes used to craft it, with each open eye representing one unexpended charge. This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

Bonerip. As a bonus action when you hit a target with this weapon, you can call the name of the demon to whom the eyes belonged and expend 1 charge. The weapon mobilises, boney teeth and necrotic energy ripping through the target's defences. The target gains a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to its AC. Its AC can't be reduced to less than 10 + its Dexterity modifier. The target can repair its armour with enough rest (for natural armour) or at an appropriate armoursmith's (for worn armour) at the GM's discretion.

A knuckle duster is a simple melee weapon, usually made of metal or another hard material, worn around the knuckles of one hand. They deal [[/r 1d4]] bludgeoning damage on a hit and have the Attached, Light, and Pugilist properties.

Attached. You can't be disarmed of this weapon, but donning or doffing the weapon takes an action. You can use a hand equipped with this weapon to hold items, but can't attack with the weapon while doing so. Additionally, you have disadvantage on attack rolls using other weapons held in a hand equipped with this weapon and on Sleight of Hand checks using the hand that is equipped with this weapon.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Pugilist. For creatures that roll a die when they make unarmed strikes (such as the monk or tavern brawler fighter), the size of their damage die is increased by one (maximum 1d12) when they make unarmed strikes with a hand equipped with a weapon that has this property.

Blood Drinker Glaive (Legendary).name: Blood Drinker Glaive (Legendary)
Blood Drinker Glaive (Legendary).description:
Weapon, legendary (requires attunement)
Martial weapon, melee weapon 6 lb.
[[/r 1d10]] slashing - heavy, reach, two-handed

The blade of this magic weapon is fashioned from the beak of a pitcrow, a nomad of the Lower Planes that feasts on the flesh and blood of fallen and wounded fiends. This polearm is able to pierce the flesh of wounded foes and absorb their blood, transferring the life force to its wielder.

While you hold this weapon, you have resistance to necrotic damage.

Syphon. If you hit a creature that has blood with an attack using this weapon on your turn and that attack leaves the creature below half of its maximum hit points, you can use a bonus action to cause the weapon to latch onto the creature and begin syphoning its blood. The creature is grappled (escape DC 16). While grappled, the creature takes [[/r 4d6]] necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns and you regain an equal number of hit points. You can't use the blood drinker to attack another target, and you must hold on to the blood drinker with at least one hand to maintain the grapple; if you let go of the blood drinker with both hands, the grapple ends. Once this property of the weapon has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Reach. This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it. This property also determines your reach for opportunity attacks with a reach weapon.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Ever parched, this sinister firearm greedily drinks any lifeblood it's offered, and an otherworldly mechanism inside it converts it into deadly shards, which it fires instead of bullets. The slightest trickle of crimson is enough for the pupils on this hellish weapon to dilate and for its eyes to appear wild and bloodshot.

Feed the Beast. This weapon has 10 charges. Over the course of a short or long rest, any creature can cause bloodshot to regain expended charges by dripping their own blood down its barrel and spending Hit Dice. Roll each Hit Die spent in this way, and the weapon regains a number of charges equal to the total. After absorbing 3 Hit Dice worth of blood, the weapon can't absorb more blood in this way until the next dawn.

Alternatively, over the course of a minute, you can extract blood from the corpse of a creature that has been dead for no longer than 10 minutes. When you do so, the weapon gains a number of charges equal to the roll of one of the dead creature's Hit Dice. After absorbing the blood from a corpse in this way, the weapon can't do so again until 1 hour has passed.

Shot Selection. This weapon doesn't have the reload or ammunition properties. Instead, in order to make a ranged weapon attack with it, you must spend charges in one of the following ways:

  • Bloodshard (1 charge). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage.

  • Septic Shock (3 charges). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage and the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the end of its next turn as its blood becomes corrupted. A creature immune to disease automatically succeeds on this saving throw.

A small, personal firearm with a rotating barrel and accuracy-enhancing rifling that deals [[/r 1d10]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 60/240), Loud (500), Reload (6) properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Loud (X). The sound of the weapon discharging alerts all hearing creatures within a number of feet as specified by the number in parentheses after the loud property. This range is doubled in echoey locations, such as cave systems, and where sound travels faster, such as underwater.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Hellscape Chatterbane Maul (Uncommon).name: Hellscape Chatterbane Maul (Uncommon)
Hellscape Chatterbane Maul (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, melee weapon 10 lb.
[[/r 2d6]] bludgeoning - heavy, two-handed

When metal is in short supply, devils and demons alike turn to more plentiful resources of the Lower Planes: teeth, bones, and molten rock. The skull of a hellscape chatterbane is often the focus of the magical enchantments weaved into it, producing flame from its eye sockets and laughter from its mouth.

While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.eCPQuQkIabFKTl9u]{Produce Flame} cantrip (+5 to hit).

Posthumous Mirth. As an action, you can shake the weapon to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.BQk5Row4NymMnUQl]{Hideous Laughter} spell (save DC 13), causing the skull's jaw to rattle up and down, and a malevolent cackling sound to fill the air. Once this property of the weapon has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Martial weapon, melee weapon 7 lb.
[[/r 1d12]] slashing - heavy, two-handed

Fashioned of bone, stone, and demon eyes, abyssal weapons are gestated by unholy bonesmiths within the infernal depths of the Hells. Fortified by magic to prevent the brittle materials from shattering, such weapons are carved with the true name of the demon whose eyes were 'donated' to its conception.

The power of such a weapon is linked to the number of eyes used to craft it, with each open eye representing one unexpended charge. This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

Bonerip. As a bonus action when you hit a target with this weapon, you can call the name of the demon to whom the eyes belonged and expend 1 charge. The weapon mobilises, boney teeth and necrotic energy ripping through the target's defences. The target gains a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to its AC. Its AC can't be reduced to less than 10 + its Dexterity modifier. The target can repair its armour with enough rest (for natural armour) or at an appropriate armoursmith's (for worn armour) at the GM's discretion.

Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Pitbone Arrow (Uncommon).description:
Ammunition, uncommon

These crude arrows thrum with energy, ready to shatter upon impact. The flights—pitcrow feathers—are enchanted to flare when a target is missed, turning the arrow to the ground where it erupts in a cloud of bone fragments. Hit or miss, these single-use arrows are a nuisance on the battlefield.

Hit. When you hit with this arrow, the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or have shattered bone fragments lodged in obtrusive places within its body. While a creature has these fragments in it, it takes 1 piercing damage when it moves for the first time on a turn and whenever it takes the Attack action. As an action, an affected creature can make a DC 13 Wisdom (Medicine) check, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Miss. When you miss with this arrow, the arrow changes direction to hit the nearest surface to the target, where it explodes into sharp fragments. Each creature within 5 feet of the arrow must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take [[/r 1d4]] piercing damage.

Shield of Retaliation (Uncommon).name: Shield of Retaliation (Uncommon)
Shield of Retaliation (Uncommon).description:
Shield (@Compendium[dnd5e.items.sSs3hSzkKBMNBgTs]{Shield}), uncommon
6 lb. AC +2

Legend says that when the war twixt fiends and celestials ravaged the Material Plane, a great infernal general had these shields forged for his captains. Through them he observed the battlefield, and with them he smote the angels that dared challenge his armies. Whether or not the fiendish general still watches through these shields, or even still lives, is a question yet to be answered.

Searing Vengeance. As a reaction when a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with an attack, you can pull a trigger on the shield's handle, causing it to breathe a plume of flame at the creature. The creature must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking [[/r 2d6]] fire damage on a failure, or half as much damage on a success. After you use this property, roll a [[/r d6]]. On a 1 or 2, the shield runs out of fuel and this property can't be used again until you feed the shield 1 gp of coal or other fuel and spend 1 hour tending to the flame (which can be done during a short or long rest), as the shield burns and chews its way through your offering.

save.condition: when a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with an attack

Emberink Stationery (Rare).name: Emberink Stationery (Rare)
Emberink Stationery (Rare).description:
Wondrous item, rare (requires attunement)

Filtered from fiendish blood, this pot of fiery orange ink melts most mundane quills that dare to dip into its contents. Only its compatriot, the enchanted pitbat quill which forms part of the stationery, can contain the lava-like liquid. An emberink stationery is often used as a training tool for new devils, promoting teamwork and the virtues of adhering to a contract.

Charges & Charging. An emberink stationery can hold a maximum of 2 charges, contains [[/r 1d4]] charges when found, and regains charges when the ink pot is used to capture a fiend's blood. As fiends' bodies disappear from the Material Plane on death, fiendish blood must be extracted while the fiend is still alive. You can use an action to extract blood from a living fiend within your reach. If the fiend is unwilling, the fiend must be restrained or incapacitated and be below half of its maximum hit points. When blood is extracted in this way, the stationery regains a number of charges equal to a roll of one of the fiend's Hit Dice, and once it regains charges, it can't do so again until the next dawn.

Contractual Obligation. As an action, you can use the stationery to write on the skin of a willing humanoid. The ink burns into the flesh of your target, raking a cauterised scar, while an identical burn appears in a similar place on your own body. Both you and the creature take 1 fire damage. Choose one of the following glyphs and expend the appropriate number of charges; for 1 hour, you are both subjected to the associated magical effects.

  • Ward (1 charge). While you and the creature are within 30 feet of one another, you both have a +1 bonus to AC. While you are more than 30 feet apart, you both suffer a -1 penalty to AC.

  • Warp (2 charges). While you and the creature are within 30 feet of one another, each affected creature can choose whether it is enlarged or reduced, as per the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.WahI41a3goVUg0x1]{Enlarge/Reduce} spell. An affected creature can use its action to return to normal size, or to enlarge or reduce itself if it's already normal size. While you are more than 30 feet apart, both creatures return to their normal size.

  • Wrath (1 charge). While you and the creature are within 30 feet of one another, you both gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls. While you are more than 30 feet apart, you both suffer a -1 penalty to attack and damage rolls.

Once the stationery has been used to sign a glyph, the ink turns dark and it can't be used again until the current contract is complete (i.e., the hour has elapsed).

Martial weapon, melee weapon [[/r 2d4]] slashing - finesse, special, two-handed

Fashioned of bone, stone, and demon eyes, abyssal weapons are gestated by unholy bonesmiths within the infernal depths of the Hells. Fortified by magic to prevent the brittle materials from shattering, such weapons are carved with the true name of the demon whose eyes were 'donated' to its conception.

The power of such a weapon is linked to the number of eyes used to craft it, with each open eye representing one unexpended charge. This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

The weapon mobilises, boney teeth and necrotic energy ripping through the target's defences. The target gains a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to its AC. Its AC can't be reduced to less than 10 + its Dexterity modifier. The target can repair its armour with enough rest (for natural armour) or at an appropriate armoursmith's (for worn armour) at the GM's discretion.

Special: Whirl. If you are proficient with the twin-blade, you can use a bonus action to attempt to whirl the weapon. Make a DC 15 Dexterity check. On a success, you gain a +2 bonus to your AC until the start of your next turn, the whirling blades acting as a barrier against attacks. On a failure, that bonus is only a +1.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Bloodshot Musket (Uncommon).name: Bloodshot Musket (Uncommon)
Bloodshot Musket (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Firearm, martial weapon, ranged weapon [[/r 1d10]] piercing - ammunition (80/240 ft.), Loud (1000), Reload (1), two-handed

Ever parched, this sinister firearm greedily drinks any lifeblood it's offered, and an otherworldly mechanism inside it converts it into deadly shards, which it fires instead of bullets. The slightest trickle of crimson is enough for the pupils on this hellish weapon to dilate and for its eyes to appear wild and bloodshot.

Feed the Beast. This weapon has 10 charges. Over the course of a short or long rest, any creature can cause bloodshot to regain expended charges by dripping their own blood down its barrel and spending Hit Dice. Roll each Hit Die spent in this way, and the weapon regains a number of charges equal to the total. After absorbing 3 Hit Dice worth of blood, the weapon can't absorb more blood in this way until the next dawn.

Alternatively, over the course of a minute, you can extract blood from the corpse of a creature that has been dead for no longer than 10 minutes. When you do so, the weapon gains a number of charges equal to the roll of one of the dead creature's Hit Dice. After absorbing the blood from a corpse in this way, the weapon can't do so again until 1 hour has passed.

Shot Selection. This weapon doesn't have the reload or ammunition properties. Instead, in order to make a ranged weapon attack with it, you must spend charges in one of the following ways:

  • Bloodshard (1 charge). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage.

  • Septic Shock (3 charges). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage and the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the end of its next turn as its blood becomes corrupted. A creature immune to disease automatically succeeds on this saving throw.

An inaccurate rifle that deals [[/r 1d10]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 80/240), Loud (1000), Reload (1), and Two-handed properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Loud (X). The sound of the weapon discharging alerts all hearing creatures within a number of feet as specified by the number in parentheses after the loud property. This range is doubled in echoey locations, such as cave systems, and where sound travels faster, such as underwater.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Soulkeeper Pendant (Very Rare).name: Soulkeeper Pendant (Very Rare)
Soulkeeper Pendant (Very Rare).description:
Wondrous item, very rare (attunement optional)

Tools of devilish origin, these mundane-looking miniature animal skulls are designed to increase the throughput of souls to the Hells.

When a humanoid dies within 5 feet of the pendant and the pendant doesn't already have a soul trapped in it, its soul becomes trapped in a flame-filled, hellish demiplane, causing the pendant's eyes to glow fiery red. Casting the remove curse spell or similar magic on the pendant releases a soul from its captivity. A soul can be stored indefinitely, and time spent in captivity within the pendant doesn't count against the time limit of resurrection spells such as raise dead. A creature who is resurrected after its soul has been stored within the pendant must make a Wisdom saving throw or develop one long-term madness effect. The DC for the saving throw equals 10 + the number of days the soul was trapped in the pendant.

Optional Attunement: Sellsoul. Upon attuning to this pendant, a devil, Eebezelbub, appears to you with an offer. She will trick souls you capture into following her to the Hells in exchange for granting you minor favours. If the pendant has a soul trapped in it, you can use an action to call Eebezelbub's name and permit her entry to the pendant. Roll a [[/r d6]]. On a 1, the soul refuses Eeb's offer and drifts away, causing the miniature animal's eyes to slowly dim. On a 2-6, the soul accepts her offer and the skull flashes brightly before petering out. Eebezelbub reappears [[/r 1d20]] minutes later, offering to perform one of the following tasks of your choice:

  • She will deliver and return one message, as per the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.GtGjNjPBgUHxGYAD]{Sending} spell, and can send the message to other planes of existence without the possibility of failure, but she can't enter good-aligned planes to deliver the message.

  • She will answer three questions, as per the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.d54VDyFulD9xxY7J]{Commune} spell.

  • She will divulge information on a topic, as per the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.W4Qx5z0id6da0vqg]{Legend Lore} spell.

Eebezelbub needs time to process the souls that accept her offers, and after getting three souls from the pendant, she won't take any more until the next dawn.

Hewn from a deformed demon's skull, this armour allows its bearer to rival the resistances of fiends. Energy is drawn in through its mouth and channelled to the eyes, where it is stored until unleashed in an elemental rebuke.

This armour has 5 charges and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

Consume Energy. When you take cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage, you can use your reaction to speak the armour's first command word and expend 1 charge. The mouth opens, consuming some of the incoming energy. You gain resistance to the triggering damage and one of the armour's eyes lights up with the stored energy. The armour has three eyes, and an eye can't store more energy if it already is storing some.

Unleash Energy. When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can utter the armour's second command word, unleashing the energy stored in all of the armour's eyes. For each eye that was storing energy, the creature takes [[/r 1d10]] damage of the stored type, after which the stored energy disappears.

As a bonus action immediately after you hit a target no more than one size larger than you with an attack using the tetherhook, you can attempt to hook the target using the tetherhook’s reach. As part of the bonus action to hook the target, and as a bonus action on any of your subsequent turns while it remains hooked, you can pull the target 5 feet closer to you, as long as it isn’t fixed in place and it weighs less than your push, drag, or lift capacity.

A knuckle duster is a simple melee weapon, usually made of metal or another hard material, worn around the knuckles of one hand. They deal [[/r 1d4]] bludgeoning damage on a hit and have the Attached, Light, and Pugilist properties.

Variant: Spiked Knuckle Dusters. This variant on the knuckleduster has the Adaptable (piercing) property.

Attached. You can't be disarmed of this weapon, but donning or doffing the weapon takes an action. You can use a hand equipped with this weapon to hold items, but can't attack with the weapon while doing so. Additionally, you have disadvantage on attack rolls using other weapons held in a hand equipped with this weapon and on Sleight of Hand checks using the hand that is equipped with this weapon.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Pugilist. For creatures that roll a die when they make unarmed strikes (such as the monk or tavern brawler fighter), the size of their damage die is increased by one (maximum 1d12) when they make unarmed strikes with a hand equipped with a weapon that has this property.

Adaptable. This weapon can be used with differing techniques, allowing it to deal different types of damage. A damage type in parentheses appears with the property—when a creature makes a weapon attack with this weapon, it can choose either the weapon's normal damage type or this damage type.

Demonic Siege Hand Tommybow (Uncommon).name: Demonic Siege Hand Tommybow (Uncommon)
Demonic Siege Hand Tommybow (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon (requires attunement by a creature with a Strength of 13 or higher)
Martial weapon, ranged weapon 3 lb.
[[/r 1d6]] piercing - ammunition (30/60 ft.), Reload (2)

What this weapon lacks in manoeuvrability, it makes up for in power. Wrought from the horns, bones, and sinew of demons, this weapon holds malice in every fibre. With its very own bracing mechanism, a user can free up a hand to fire using both strings at once.

The damage die of this weapon is increased by one size (e.g., a longbow deals [[/r 1d10]] damage, a shortbow deals [[/r 1d8]]). The bow has 2 charges and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

Siege Brace. As a bonus action, you can expend 1 charge and speak the bow's command word, causing a skeletal, demonic hand to burst from the ground or another surface and hold the bow steady until you use another bonus action to dismiss it. The bow can't be moved while grasped by the skeletal hand, and a successful DC 13 Strength check using an action is required to wrest it from this grasp. While in this 'siege mode', each time you make a ranged weapon attack using this bow, you can make one additional attack against the same target (no action required). When you do so, both attacks are made with disadvantage.

Tommybows are repeating crossbows that mirror the three types of normal crossbows: hand, heavy, and light. They are composed of vertically-stacked bows upon a crossbow's chassis, an unwieldy arrangement that reduces their effective range in comparison to their crossbow counterparts.

Tommybows replace the loading property of their crossbow counterpart with the reload property. The cost of the item is proportional to the amount of ammunition it can hold (the value in parentheses), with the maximum reload (6) tommybow costing six times its crossbow counterpart's price.

Special. You have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.

Reach. This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it. This property also determines your reach for opportunity attacks with a reach weapon.

Weapon, rare
Martial weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d4]] piercing - ammunition (20/60 ft.), finesse, light, thrown (20/60 ft.), Thrown Versatility ([[/r 1d4]])

When metal is in short supply, devils and demons alike turn to more plentiful resources of the Lower Planes: teeth, bones, and molten rock. The skull of a hellscape chatterbane is often the focus of the magical enchantments weaved into it, producing flame from its eye sockets and laughter from its mouth.

While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.eCPQuQkIabFKTl9u]{Produce Flame} cantrip as a 5th-level caster (+7 to hit).

Posthumous Mirth. Once this property of the weapon has been used four times, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Starknives are martial melee weapons; three to five double-edged blades set on a central handle that are most effective as thrown weapons but can also be used for close combat. Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Thrown Versatility. This weapon is better used for thrown ranged weapon attacks than for melee weapon attacks. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used to make a ranged weapon attack.

Bloodshot Rifle (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Firearm, martial weapon, ranged weapon [[/r 1d12]] piercing - ammunition (120/480 ft.), Loud (500), Reload (6), two-handed

Ever parched, this sinister firearm greedily drinks any lifeblood it's offered, and an otherworldly mechanism inside it converts it into deadly shards, which it fires instead of bullets. The slightest trickle of crimson is enough for the pupils on this hellish weapon to dilate and for its eyes to appear wild and bloodshot.

Feed the Beast. This weapon has 10 charges. Over the course of a short or long rest, any creature can cause bloodshot to regain expended charges by dripping their own blood down its barrel and spending Hit Dice. Roll each Hit Die spent in this way, and the weapon regains a number of charges equal to the total. After absorbing 3 Hit Dice worth of blood, the weapon can't absorb more blood in this way until the next dawn.

Alternatively, over the course of a minute, you can extract blood from the corpse of a creature that has been dead for no longer than 10 minutes. When you do so, the weapon gains a number of charges equal to the roll of one of the dead creature's Hit Dice. After absorbing the blood from a corpse in this way, the weapon can't do so again until 1 hour has passed.

Shot Selection. This weapon doesn't have the reload or ammunition properties. Instead, in order to make a ranged weapon attack with it, you must spend charges in one of the following ways:

  • Bloodshard (1 charge). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage.

  • Septic Shock (3 charges). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage and the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the end of its next turn as its blood becomes corrupted. A creature immune to disease automatically succeeds on this saving throw.

The longest range of all the firearms, typically equipped with a multi-bullet magazine, it deals [[/r 1d12]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 120/480), Loud (500), Reload (6), and Two-handed properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Martial weapon, melee weapon 6 lb.
[[/r 1d10]] slashing - heavy, reach, two-handed

The blade of this magic weapon is fashioned from the beak of a pitcrow, a nomad of the Lower Planes that feasts on the flesh and blood of fallen and wounded fiends. This polearm is able to pierce the flesh of wounded foes and absorb their blood, transferring the life force to its wielder.

Syphon. If you hit a creature that has blood with an attack using this weapon on your turn and that attack leaves the creature below half of its maximum hit points, you can use a bonus action to cause the weapon to latch onto the creature and begin syphoning its blood. The creature is grappled (escape DC 16). While grappled, the creature takes [[/r 4d6]] necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns and you regain an equal number of hit points. You can't use the blood drinker to attack another target, and you must hold on to the blood drinker with at least one hand to maintain the grapple; if you let go of the blood drinker with both hands, the grapple ends. Once this property of the weapon has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Thrown. If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Thrown Versatility. This weapon is better used for thrown ranged weapon attacks than for melee weapon attacks. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used to make a ranged weapon attack.

When metal is in short supply, devils and demons alike turn to more plentiful resources of the Lower Planes: teeth, bones, and molten rock. Posthumous Mirth. Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

Simple weapon, melee weapon 2 lb.

The power of such a weapon is linked to the number of eyes used to craft it, with each open eye representing one unexpended charge. This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

Its AC can't be reduced to less than 10 + its Dexterity modifier. The target can repair its armour with enough rest (for natural armour) or at an appropriate armoursmith's (for worn armour) at the GM's discretion.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Mirror of Truesight (Very Rare).description:
Wondrous item, very rare

Nothing so delicate as glass or so pure as silver survives long on the Lower Planes. That in itself makes this magic item a rarity. Held by a handle of claw-like fingers, this magic mirror grants its user the ability to see who is truly the fairest of them all.

Pluckpatch (Rare).description:
Wondrous item, rare (requires attunement)

This plain, worn, leather eyepatch is an unassuming addition to any treasure hoard. However, upon attunement, three eyes are plucked from 'donor' fiends in the Hells in order to slowly orbit around your head. Whether fiends are willing donors or victims of a crafty wizard's devilish machinations is an unanswered moral dilemma.

This eyepatch has 7 charges, represented by the seven floating eyeballs, and regains [[/r 1d6 + 1]] expended charges daily at dawn.

Peekaboo. As an action, you can expend 1 charge to telepathically link yourself to one eyeball for the next 10 minutes. While linked, you see through the eyeball, which has darkvision out to 120 feet, and you are blind with regards to your own vision. As a bonus action while linked to the eyeball, you can move the eyeball up to 30 feet in any direction. There is no limit to how far away from you the eye can move, but it can't enter another plane of existence. The eyeball has 2 hit points, an AC of 15, and a Dexterity (Stealth) modifier of +10. If the eyeball is reduced to 0 hit points or you sever the connection (no action required), the eyeball disappears, returning to its fiendish donor.

The power of such a weapon is linked to the number of eyes used to craft it, with each open eye representing one unexpended charge. This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Bonerip. As a bonus action when you hit a target with this weapon, you can call the name of the demon to whom the eyes belonged and expend 1 charge. The weapon mobilises, boney teeth and necrotic energy ripping through the target's defences. The target gains a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to its AC. Its AC can't be reduced to less than 10 + its Dexterity modifier. The target can repair its armour with enough rest (for natural armour) or at an appropriate armoursmith's (for worn armour) at the GM's discretion.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

Thrown. If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

Thrown Versatility. This weapon is better used for thrown ranged weapon attacks than for melee weapon attacks. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used to make a ranged weapon attack.

Weapon, uncommon
Martial weapon, melee weapon [[/r 1d8]] piercing - reach, special, two-handed

When metal is in short supply, devils and demons alike turn to more plentiful resources of the Lower Planes: teeth, bones, and molten rock. The skull of a hellscape chatterbane is often the focus of the magical enchantments weaved into it, producing flame from its eye sockets and laughter from its mouth.

While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.eCPQuQkIabFKTl9u]{Produce Flame} cantrip (+5 to hit).

Posthumous Mirth. As an action, you can shake the weapon to cast the @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.BQk5Row4NymMnUQl]{Hideous Laughter} spell (save DC 13), causing the skull's jaw to rattle up and down, and a malevolent cackling sound to fill the air. Once this property of the weapon has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

A tetherhook is a martial melee weapon with the Reach, Two-handed, and Special: Hookpull properties. It is comprised of a hook attached to a chain or strap and deals [[/r 1d8]] piercing damage on a hit.

Special: Hookpull. As a bonus action immediately after you hit a target no more than one size larger than you with an attack using the tetherhook, you can attempt to hook the target using the tetherhook’s reach. Make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target’s Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (the target chooses the ability to use). If you succeed, the target is hooked and can’t move further away from you. A hooked creature is no longer hooked if you release the tether with both hands, but only one hand is required to keep a creature hooked. A hooked creature can use its action to escape. To do so, it must succeed on a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by your Strength (Athletics) check.

As part of the bonus action to hook the target, and as a bonus action on any of your subsequent turns while it remains hooked, you can pull the target 5 feet closer to you, as long as it isn’t fixed in place and it weighs less than your push, drag, or lift capacity.

Reach. This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it. This property also determines your reach for opportunity attacks with a reach weapon.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Bloodshot Pistol (Uncommon).name: Bloodshot Pistol (Uncommon)
Bloodshot Pistol (Uncommon).description:
Weapon, uncommon
Firearm, martial weapon, ranged weapon [[/r 1d8]] piercing - ammunition (40/120 ft.), Loud (500), Reload (2)

Ever parched, this sinister firearm greedily drinks any lifeblood it's offered, and an otherworldly mechanism inside it converts it into deadly shards, which it fires instead of bullets. The slightest trickle of crimson is enough for the pupils on this hellish weapon to dilate and for its eyes to appear wild and bloodshot.

Feed the Beast. This weapon has 10 charges. Over the course of a short or long rest, any creature can cause bloodshot to regain expended charges by dripping their own blood down its barrel and spending Hit Dice. Roll each Hit Die spent in this way, and the weapon regains a number of charges equal to the total. After absorbing 3 Hit Dice worth of blood, the weapon can't absorb more blood in this way until the next dawn.

Alternatively, over the course of a minute, you can extract blood from the corpse of a creature that has been dead for no longer than 10 minutes. When you do so, the weapon gains a number of charges equal to the roll of one of the dead creature's Hit Dice. After absorbing the blood from a corpse in this way, the weapon can't do so again until 1 hour has passed.

Shot Selection. This weapon doesn't have the reload or ammunition properties. Instead, in order to make a ranged weapon attack with it, you must spend charges in one of the following ways:

  • Bloodshard (1 charge). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage.

  • Septic Shock (3 charges). On a hit, the weapon deals its normal damage and the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the end of its next turn as its blood becomes corrupted. A creature immune to disease automatically succeeds on this saving throw.

A small, personal, double-barreled firearm that deals [[/r 1d8]] piercing damage on a hit. It has the Ammunition (range 40/120), Loud (500), Reload (2) properties.

Extra Reloads. More expensive models of magitech firearms have a self-reloading mechanism that harnesses the arcanomagnetic engine to re-cock the weapon. If you wish, you can increase the magazine capacity of a magitech firearm up to a maximum of 6, ensuring that the price increases proportionally. For example, a pistol typically costs 200 gp and has reload (2). If you increased this to reload (6), you would multiply the price by 3 for a new cost of 600 gp.

Range. A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

Ammunition. You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Loud (X). The sound of the weapon discharging alerts all hearing creatures within a number of feet as specified by the number in parentheses after the loud property. This range is doubled in echoey locations, such as cave systems, and where sound travels faster, such as underwater.

Reload (X). A limited number of shots, specified by the number in parentheses after the reload property, can be made with this weapon. A character must then reload it using an action.

Light. A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

[[/r 1d8]] piercing - finesse

Fashioned of bone, stone, and demon eyes, abyssal weapons are gestated by unholy bonesmiths within the infernal depths of the Hells. Fortified by magic to prevent the brittle materials from shattering, such weapons are carved with the true name of the demon whose eyes were 'donated' to its conception.

The power of such a weapon is linked to the number of eyes used to craft it, with each open eye representing one unexpended charge. This weapon has 2 charges, and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

Bonerip. As a bonus action when you hit a target with this weapon, you can call the name of the demon to whom the eyes belonged and expend 1 charge. The weapon mobilises, boney teeth and necrotic energy ripping through the target's defences. The target gains a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to its AC. Its AC can't be reduced to less than 10 + its Dexterity modifier. The target can repair its armour with enough rest (for natural armour) or at an appropriate armoursmith's (for worn armour) at the GM's discretion.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Demonbane Armour Half Plate Armor (Uncom.description:
Medium armor, uncommon
40 lb. AC 15 + Dex (max 2)

Hewn from a deformed demon's skull, this armour allows its bearer to rival the resistances of fiends. Energy is drawn in through its mouth and channelled to the eyes, where it is stored until unleashed in an elemental rebuke.

This armour has 2 charges and regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

Consume Energy. When you take cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage, you can use your reaction to speak the armour's first command word and expend 1 charge. The mouth opens, consuming some of the incoming energy. You gain resistance to the triggering damage and one of the armour's eyes lights up with the stored energy. The armour has one eyes, and an eye can't store more energy if it already is storing some.

Unleash Energy. When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can utter the armour's second command word, unleashing the energy stored in all of the armour's eyes. For each eye that was storing energy, the creature takes [[/r 1d6]] damage of the stored type, after which the stored energy disappears.

The wearer has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.
